record.text: Anyone writing JS today should be using Prettier or equivalent to format their code, really. It also uses semicolons by default which is indeed the sane option.
Yeah, there's really nothing wrong with random drops as a gameplay mechanic as long as you're simply not paying real money for it

Of course event the original idea was frankly terrible because an industry being new is the best time to give honest and detailed feedback about its output, because that's when they'll most likely listen and react to the feedback the most, setting hopefully good practices for the years to come.

The silliest thing is that this whole idea of "criticizing the industry would kill the industry!" is woefully outdated, originating from when the western anime industry was small and new. But that hasn't been the case in forever, especially not today with literally Sony owning most of it.

Like sure I was a fansubber in the past but even back then my biggest wish was that legal options would make fansubbing truly obsolete. Plus I've literally been working in the western industry on the manga publishing side for 10+ years by now. But never let facts get in the way of hatin' I guess

To be fair, she has been weirdly antagonistic toward me for a long time, because apparently me wanting the western anime industry to receive regular criticism & commentary on release quality for the sake of bettering the industry is actually a conspiracy to kill said industry via piracy or something

I've been gaining a steady amount of blocks after posting my thread on standing up for artistic freedom on principle. Which was to be expected, really, considering how common anti tendencies are today. Getting blocked by the editor in chief of ANN out of nowhere was a bit unexpected though.

Honestly pretty wild that someone would actually do that, it's not like it takes that long to read a single light novel volume... Like I've read some stuff that I really ended up disliking but even then I still at least finished the first volume, and I'm just reading for fun!

It's ridiculous how successfully publishers have managed to boil their frogs with how everyone (press & players) just casually seems to accept such invasive and ridiculous requirements for SINGLE PLAYER GAMES just because they happen to be free*

*You can spend an infinite amount of money gambling

If this is the direction that big budget single player games are heading in then count me the fuck out forever. I'm not giving any damn company, much less a Chinese one, unchecked root access to my computer with a constant internet connection just to play a fucking gambling machine

If you're new to payment processor news: welcome! These exist to spread awareness of the unchecked extrajuridicial power that credit card companies et al have over who is allowed to make money and a living on the internet and how they regularly abuse this power to stomp on especially adult content.

Yeah, like great fucking job, you've appealed to some racist dumbfucks by making your food less tasty, congratulations!!!

Though at least here some manufacturers just found some mushrooms with basically the exact same chemical compounds as MSG to replace it while being able to legally say "no MSG!"
Same, and also goes for anything advertising itself along the lines of "(now with) no MSG!"

I have somewhat mixed feelings. Technical progress making faking stuff is unfortunately just part of the package, and trying to prevent it could have a lot of unintended consequences. Cultural education and more tech would be the least bad way to solve things, but those take time and effort to root

The sanitization is something that also rubs me very much the wrong way about the whole genAI business, because just about everything about it is coming off as very anti-general computing, including most of the legislative talk related to it
Literally just repeating "but it's icky!" but in slightly different words

Then ethical training of genAI as per part A would obviously be a lot easier and more powerful, because our public domain would be vastly more expansive. Alas, while such copyright reform would be immensely good for the world, I doubt we'll ever see it, so genAI should play by the rules we have. 6/6

I guess that about sums it up. One additional thing worth mentioning is that I'm also a big copyleft nerd and believe the current copyright regime is rotten to the core and should be revamped so that copyright lasts around 10 years at most. If we lived in a world like that... 5/

e) one additional area not often talked about where I believe genAI poses one of the greatest dangers is that of legislation. Fear of AI by politicians could lead to some extremely poorly thought anti-general computing laws all over the world, which could have massively troublesome outcomes. 4/

where basically all our planet was running on abundant nuclear and green energy, there really shouldn't be any theoretical problems with "wasting" a bunch of energy playing around with stuff like genAI. Alas, that is not the world we live in today, unfortunately. 3/

c) the current genAI hype is extremely rotten due to basically all of it failing on part A above and it being proposed as a miracle cure-all for everything, failing on part B too d) that the environmental impact can't be understated either due to its failings. However, in a better world 2/

I am not completely anti-genAI per se, but I believe a) any genAI should be trained exclusively on public domain or otherwise fully and rightfully cleared materials and b) there are many tasks which genAI is just not suited for (eg. translating fiction) because of the nature of how LLMs work 1/
Scrapers are an inevitable part of the open web, and the open web is more valuable than trying to prevent scraping at any cost

Guess all those LGBT book bans are totally fine and dandy to you then, just the acceptable cost of business for being able to punish those icky drawing likers. I'm sure the minorities will be thankful for the stunning moral principles you have displayed here today

Once again, you can't make a meaningful distinction between the stuff you linked and me taking that stick figure from earlier and scribbling "10yo" or so next to it. It's all non-photorealistic stylized drawings. "I know it when I see it" is not sufficient as it actively fuels real world oppression.

Wouldn't change the fact that you were calling a drawing of an adult anime character a child, making my point about how trying to draw clear lines about what'd be "ban worthy" is basically impossible. You've already muddled any possible line you could have drawn beyond repair, opening it for abuse
You're basically proving my point about not being able to meaningfully distinguish things considering that image is of Kikuri Hiroi, a 25-year old alcoholic bassist from Bocchi the Rock

As a final note here I want to remind you all that right wingers are actively using "I know it when I see it" as a justification to call LGBT content aimed at children "pedophilia" and are actively banning books in schools and libraries in US. Which is why standing up even for icky art is important.

Uh huh, sure, I'm soooo much more dangerous than the right wingers and other regularly intolerant across who'd love to eradicate you from the face of the earth solely for being a furry. Totally. Hope you have fun with the bedfellows you're choosing here.
Enjoying erotic drawings is certainly a kink no matter what kind of drawings they are specifically. None of this discussion is about real kids

I know, my followup was to clarify that while some people might be into some niche kink due to unfortunate circumstances, you don't really need a justification like that to enjoy specific kinks because kinks don't inform one's moral character regardless.

Liking whatever kinky fiction shouldn't really be any more taboo than liking whatever other kinky fiction when producing and consuming them doesn't hurt anyone. If sexy times are involved, you should limit talk of them to appropriate adult circumstances, but that's basically it.

Look, I'm not interested in looking for actual loli art to share as examples here. But Aoba on the right there isn't far from what could be called a "loli" in a different context. And I could've written 10yo next to the stick figure too. Once again, you can't draw a clear line with stylized NPR art.

But hey, since a "reasonable person" will Know When They See It (which is what you are giving your approval for here), I guess you don't mind all those right wingers banning LGBT books talking about sex for "pedophilia" then since that's what it "reasonably" is for them. Just the cost of business :)

And what exactly is left for the bailey if lolisho etc is already in the motte?

And what's your answer to the question posed in the quoted post? If that isn't bannable, then where is the line? "I know it when I see it" is not a sufficient answer as that's incredibly easy for bad actors to abuse

While there are probably artists out there that have referenced real CSAM for their drawings, it's crazy to suggest that it would be in any way a common thing - I've never heard of a confirmed case myself in the two decades I've been the anime scene. The real amount is likely vanishingly small.
See my followup, I don't think he should have been convicted based on this alone.

Regardless, I do feel that without something more concrete than just "distributing obscenity" he shouldn't have been convicted, because the whole idea of speech / artistic expression becoming illegal solely due to being "obscene" really shouldn't be a thing IMHO.

Yeah, from what I've read, basically every conviction in the US dealing with drawn materials either a) involved actual CSAM too or b) the defendant plead guilty early (like with Handley). CBLDF has assisted in legal proceedings dealing in just drawings since with success

The meaning is perfectly clear when you don't try to be obtuse about it. Nazis are nazis because they want the supremacy of the few at the cost of the many. Clearly want to limit other's expression by definition. Same for any anti-LGBT preaching religionaries. They broke the contract, so shut em up.

Legal is indeed not the ideal word globally speaking. To be comprehensive you'd need something like "art in which nobody was hurt in the creation without their consent" or so but that's kind of hard to express succinctly so I had to settle for the non optimal shorthand of legal for the sake of space

Of course, you need a sufficient amount of media literacy to make an accurate judgment in this regard, since mere depiction of something does not automatically mean endorsing it (the fact that this even needs to be said is rather sad but that's where we're at today)
Indeed! If you use your freedom of expression to say that others shouldn't have the same freedom, you lose your own right to be heard on account of being a hypocrite and breaking the social contract
Let's also not forget how consistently conservatives like to vote in favor of laws allowing children to get married to adults 🤢
Someone else's one ton torpedo goes brrr while you're sitting in tenpai for thirteen orphans (happened to me just the other day)

Grooming is bad no matter what and doesn't require specialized porn to be effective. As such trying to ban lolisho would do approximately fuckall to combat it. Anyone genuinely wanting to prevent grooming should be first and foremost arguing for good and comprehensive sex education in schools.
Just report, block, and move on, don't give em a reaction of any kind
In other words, the puriteen culture is right wing culture masquerading as left wing while being anything but left wing in reality.

It's understandable how one could feel conflicted about it. Just remember that at the end of the day, the thing that truly matters in terms of being a good person is how you treat other real people. Not what media you consume.

There is a very real slippery slope to banning from social and moral condemnation. The most that society at large should do is ensure that presence is limited to appropriate places (ie. adult content should stick to adult spaces - on social media, that'd include accounts labeled as adults only)

I don't know this person at all. But I've had plenty of run-ins with volatile antis over my stance (including earlier today) and this person's "I get what you mean but it still feels wrong to me and I don't really know how to deal with it" is very much not volatile anti behavior

This line of thinking isn't really any different from "playing violent video games makes you violent". Someone with real life violent tendencies may also enjoy violent video games but this does not automatically make the opposite true and the same applies with anything else fictional.
How about we don't make assumptions about each other and instead engage with what was actually said in good faith.

Worrying about it at all is just extremely pointless because at the end of the day we are not talking about real people but fictional, stylized, unreal constructs. There are plenty of things one can like in fiction that they wouldn't like to see or experience in real life. It's perfectly normal.
If your expression is all about how you want to stop others from expressing themselves, you break the social contract and void your own right of expression.

And this is not a slippery slope or a hypothetical in any way. It is actively happening today all around the world, including in the United States. If you haven't been paying attention to all the book bans etc targeting minorities, you should. Because that's where not standing for icky art leads.

And no, "I'll know it when I see it" is not a sufficient answer. Ultimately, any attempt to ban legal art for being icky will only end up serving as ammunition for right wingers and other bad actors to use as a cudgel against minorities, whose existence they'll try to ban by claiming it as icky.
